variant.question: Why is strict adherence to flight director guidance important when manually flying a radius to fix (RF) leg? The flight director...

options.text: is required to provide the necessary level of guidance and precision during the turn.
allows the pilot to cross-check the DME arc guidance along the RF procedure.
provides guidance based on a fixed radius calculated with current TAS and bank angle.
must be used in place of the autopilot as it provides more precise guidance.

variant.question: Why must the flight director be used for guidance when flying an RF leg without the autopilot?

options.text: The RF leg is based on a fixed radius turn with guidance calculated by the aircraft's RNAV system.
The RNP system uploads the RF procedure to the FAC, which then provides guidance via the flight director.
The flight director displays guidance based on the information received from ground-based transmitters.
The flight director will give a visual and audible alert if the actual navigation performance exceeds the RNP during the RF leg.

variant.question: Which statement is true regarding an offset flight path?

options.text: It allows the crew to specify a lateral offset from a defined route
It allows the crew to specify a vertical offset from a defined route
An offset flight path is used for holding
An offset flight path is used for parallel approaches in terminal areas
